programs.name: 2-1-1 Bay Area

programs.fullDescription: Free help completing the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) is available through California Cash for College workshops and other programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free in-person FAFSA completion workshops
- Help with California Dream Act Application
- One-on-one assistance with financial aid forms
- Virtual and in-person options available
- Bilingual assistance in many locations
- Help understanding financial aid awards
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Find a Cash for College workshop near you
2. Bring required documents (tax returns, Social Security numbers, etc.)
3. Work with trained volunteers to complete FAFSA
4. Get help understanding next steps
5. Workshops held at schools, libraries, and community centers
programs.keywords: FAFSA, financial aid, college, federal aid, Pell Grant, student loans, free help, application, form, CSAC, Cash for College

programs.name: Federal Pell Grant
programs.description: Up to $7,395/year in free federal grant money for college (no repayment)
programs.fullDescription: The Federal Pell Grant provides free money for college to undergraduate students with financial need. Unlike loans, Pell Grants do not need to be repaid.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Up to $7,395 per year (2024-2025)
- Free money - no repayment required
- Can be used for tuition, fees, books, and living expenses
- Available at most colleges and universities
- Can be combined with other financial aid
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Complete the FAFSA at studentaid.gov
2. Must demonstrate financial need (based on EFC)
3. Must be pursuing undergraduate degree
4. Must be enrolled at least half-time
5. Must be U.S. citizen or eligible noncitizen
6. Amount depends on financial need, cost of attendance, and enrollment status
programs.keywords: Pell Grant, federal aid, financial aid, FAFSA, college, free money, undergraduate, low-income, student aid

programs.name: Head Start / Early Head Start
programs.description: Free comprehensive early childhood education, health services, and meals for children birth to age 5
programs.fullDescription: Head Start provides free early childhood education, health, nutrition, and family support services to children from low-income families from birth to age 5.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free preschool education for children 3-5 years
- Early Head Start for infants and toddlers (0-3)
- Health and developmental screenings
- Nutritious meals and snacks
- Parent engagement and family support services
- Disability services and inclusion support
- Full-day and part-day options available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Income must be at or below federal poverty guidelines
2. Or child is in foster care, homeless, or receiving public assistance
3. Contact local Head Start agency to apply
4. Complete application and provide income documentation
5. Children are prioritized based on need
programs.keywords: Head Start, Early Head Start, preschool, free preschool, early childhood, pre-K, low-income, child development, childcare, 3-5 years, infant, toddler

programs.description: Book vouchers, priority registration, counseling, and additional grants for low-income community college students

programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Priority registration
- Book vouchers and supplies
- Academic counseling
- Transfer assistance
- Grant aid (in addition to other financial aid)

programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be enrolled at California Community College
2. Must meet income eligibility requirements

programs.name: Free & Reduced School Meals
programs.description: Free or reduced-price breakfast and lunch at school for qualifying students
programs.fullDescription: California schools provide free breakfast and lunch to students who qualify based on family income, and many districts now offer universal free meals to all students.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free or reduced-price breakfast and lunch
- Many California districts now offer free meals to ALL students
- Nutritious meals meeting federal nutrition standards
- Available during school year
- Some districts offer summer meal programs
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Complete free/reduced meal application through your school
2. Household income must be at or below 185% of poverty for reduced price
3. Household income at or below 130% for free meals
4. Children in CalFresh, CalWORKs, or foster care automatically qualify
5. Many California districts provide universal free meals regardless of income
programs.keywords: free lunch, school meals, reduced lunch, breakfast, NSLP, school breakfast, children, low-income, food, hunger

- Available at parks, libraries, schools, community centers

programs.name: EDD Unemployment Insurance (UI)

programs.fullDescription: California's Unemployment Insurance program provides temporary financial assistance to workers who lost their jobs through no fault of their own while they search for new employment.

programs.fullDescription: The California Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise (DVBE) program helps veteran-owned businesses win state contracts. Certified DVBE businesses receive preference in state purchasing and contracting, with a goal that 3% of state contracts go to DVBEs.

programs.howToGetIt:
1. Business must be at least 51% owned by service-disabled veteran

5. Complete DVBE application online
6. Wait for certification review (typically 30-45 days)

programs.name: Disabled Veteran Property Tax Exemption
programs.description: Property tax exemption up to $241,627 assessed value for disabled veterans; based on disability rating and income
programs.fullDescription: California offers one of the nation's most valuable property tax exemptions for disabled veterans. The exemption can eliminate thousands in annual property taxes based on disability rating and income level.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Full or partial property tax exemption
- Basic exemption up to $161,083 (2024) for 100% disabled
- Low-income exemption up to $241,627 (2024) for qualifying veterans
- Applies to primary residence only
- Unmarried surviving spouses may also qualify
- Annual savings can be thousands of dollars
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must have service-connected disability from VA
2. Must be California resident
3. Property must be primary residence
4. File claim with County Assessor's Office
5. Provide VA disability rating letter and DD214
6. Renew annually with county
programs.keywords: disabled veteran, property tax exemption, VA disability, service-connected disability, property tax relief, homeowner, tax savings, surviving spouse, county assessor

programs.name: CalEITC  California Earned Income Tax Credit
programs.description: Cash back up to $3,529 for working individuals; plus $1,117 Young Child Tax Credit; available to ITIN filers
programs.fullDescription: The California Earned Income Tax Credit (CalEITC) provides cash back to low-income working Californians. Combined with the federal EITC, families can receive thousands of dollars in tax refunds even if they owe no taxes.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Cash back tax credit up to $3,529 (varies by income/family size)
- Refundable credit  get money even if you owe no taxes
- Young Child Tax Credit adds up to $1,117 for children under 6
- Can be combined with federal EITC for larger refund
- Available to ITIN filers (undocumented workers)
- No minimum age requirement (federal EITC requires age 25+)
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Earned income must be under ~$30,950 (varies by family size)
2. File California state tax return (Form 540)
3. Complete Schedule CalEITC
4. Claim Young Child Tax Credit if you have children under 6
5. Use free tax prep services (VITA) for help filing
6. File by April 15 to receive refund
programs.keywords: CalEITC, California Earned Income Tax Credit, EITC, tax refund, cash back, low income, working families, Young Child Tax Credit, ITIN, undocumented

programs.name: Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher Program
programs.description: Rental subsidy covering difference between 30% of income and fair market rent
programs.fullDescription: The Housing Choice Voucher (Section 8) program helps low-income families, seniors, and people with disabilities afford rental housing by subsidizing a portion of rent paid to private landlords.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Monthly rental subsidy paid directly to landlord
- Tenant pays approximately 30% of income toward rent
- Choice to rent in private market (not just public housing)
- Portability to move between housing authorities
- Protection from paying more than 30-40% of income for housing
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Apply through your local housing authority
2. Must meet income limits (generally below 50% of area median income)
3. Waitlists are often long (years in some areas)
4. Some housing authorities open waitlists periodically
5. When your name comes up, attend briefing and find housing
6. Housing authority inspects unit and approves rent
programs.keywords: Section 8, housing voucher, HCV, rent assistance, HUD, low-income housing, rental subsidy, waitlist, public housing

programs.name: California Emergency Rental Assistance
programs.description: Payment of past-due rent and utilities to prevent eviction
programs.fullDescription: California's Emergency Rental Assistance Program helps income-eligible renters who have been impacted by the pandemic pay past-due rent and utilities to avoid eviction.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Payment of past-due rent (up to 18 months)
- Payment of past-due utilities
- Future rent assistance in some cases
- Eviction protection while application pending
- Direct payment to landlord/utility company
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit HousingIsKey.com or call 833-430-2122
2. Must be income-eligible (80% of area median income or below)
3. Must have COVID-related financial hardship
4. Must have past-due rent or utilities
5. Submit application with required documentation
6. Landlord participation required for rent assistance
programs.keywords: emergency rental assistance, rent help, COVID, back rent, utility help, eviction prevention, California, low-income

programs.name: Court Fee Waivers
programs.description: Filing fees waived
programs.fullDescription: California courts offer fee waivers for individuals who cannot afford to pay court filing fees, ensuring access to the justice system regardless of income.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waiver of court filing fees
- Waiver of motion fees and jury fees
- Waiver of fees for court-appointed interpreter
- Free copies of necessary court documents
- Fee waiver for court reporter services in some cases
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Obtain Form FW-001 (Request to Waive Court Fees) from the court clerk or online
2. Complete the form with income and household information
3. You automatically qualify if you receive public benefits (Medi-Cal, CalFresh, SSI, etc.)
4. Or if household income is 125% or below Federal Poverty Level
5. Submit form to the court clerk before or with your first court filing
6. Judge will review and approve or deny within 5 court days
programs.keywords: court fee waiver, filing fees, FW-001, low-income, legal, lawsuit, sue, motion fees, jury fees, court documents, Medi-Cal, CalFresh, SSI, public benefits, free court

programs.name: USCIS I-912 Fee Waiver
programs.description: Waiver of filing fees for certain immigration forms based on income/benefits
programs.fullDescription: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) offers fee waivers for certain immigration applications for individuals who cannot afford the filing fees.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waiver of filing fees for certain immigration forms
- Available for naturalization (N-400), green card renewal (I-90), and other forms
- Based on income, receipt of means-tested benefits, or financial hardship
- Does not affect your immigration case or chances of approval
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Download Form I-912 from uscis.gov
2. Determine your basis for fee waiver (means-tested benefit, income below 150% FPL, or hardship)
3. Gather supporting documents (benefit letters, tax returns, pay stubs)
4. Submit I-912 with your immigration application
5. USCIS will review and notify you of approval or denial
6. If denied, you must pay the fee to continue your application

- Free vehicle day-use entry to 200+ state parks
- Covers 1 vehicle with up to 9 people or 1 motorcycle
- Valid at participating state parks statewide
- Does not cover camping or special events
- Does not cover museums within parks
programs.howToGetIt:

programs.name: Cordell Bank National Marine Sanctuary
programs.description: Entirely offshore, Cordell Bank National Marine Sanctuary protects soft seafloor habitat, a rocky bank, deep-sea canyons, and diverse wildlife, while acting as a feeding ground for many marine mammals and seabirds. This protected area is home to several habitats and species that can be visited from afar through educational resources such as panels and exhibits. Visitors can enjoy this extraordinarily rich marine ecosystem by boating, fishing, and watching wildlife from the mainland.

programs.name: Elkhorn Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve
programs.description: Elkhorn Slough is one of the relatively few undisturbed coastal wetlands remaining in California. The main channel of the slough, which winds inland nearly seven miles, is flanked by a broad salt marsh second in size only to San Francisco Bay. programs.name: Knoxville Recreation Area
programs.description: Due to its close proximity to the Sacramento and San Francisco Bay Area regions, and because of its varied terrain, Knoxville's 17,700 acres attract many off-highway vehicle (OHV) enthusiasts each year. The landscape is characterized by steep and rolling hills with the vegetation varying from scattered hardwoods and grasses to dense chaparral brush. California gray pine and Macnab cypress are also dispersed throughout the area. Of particular note, are unusual plant communities unique to the area

programs.name: Lake Berryessa
programs.description: Nestled between Blue Ridge and Cedar Roughs, east of the Napa Valley, Lake Berryessa offers year-round recreation opportunities. Lake Berryessa's water reaches temperatures of up to 75 degrees in the summer, making it an ideal place for water sports. Anglers enjoy fishing for both cold and warm water species, such as rainbow trout, bass, catfish, crappie, and bluegill. The Bureau of Reclamation provides two large day use areas (Oak Shores and Smittle Creek), Capell Cove launch ramp, and many sma

programs.description: Overview Liberty Glen Campground is located at the top of Rockpile Road overlooking Lake Sonoma. World famous vineyards and a rich history surround the lake, where visitors enjoy boating, fishing and exploring the area's extensive trail network. programs.howToGetIt:

- Standard entrance fee: $15-$35 per vehicle (where applicable)
- Alcatraz ferry tickets sold separately

programs.name: Nimbus Fish Hatchery
programs.description: Nimbus Dam , on the American River 7 miles below Folsom Dam formed Lake Natoma to reregulate the releases for power made through Folsom Powerplant. Nimbus Dam is a feature of the Central Valley Project - American River Division - Folsom and Sly Park Units . Open year-round for fish rearing and educational actvities. Fish

programs.name: S F Bay Model Regional Visitor Center
programs.description: The Bay Model was built in 1957 as a research tool to test the impact of proposed changes to San Francisco Bay and its related waterways. The model has been used to study the effects of chemical/oil spills, altering of shipping channels, levee failures, and bay in-filling. The hydraulic model was used to simulate currents, tidal action, sediment movement and the mixing of fresh and salt water. In 1980 the visitor center portion was added, and the Model adopted the function of an Educational Cent

programs.description: The San Francisco Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve comprises two components located along the salinity gradient of the San Francisco Bay. Facilities open for use Wednesday through Sunday. Operation hours: sunrise to sunset. Good access roads. The park offers recreation to anglers, boaters, windsurfers, picnickers, and mountain bikers. Boat size restricted to 16 feet. Gas engines prohibited. Ideal for small sailboats and windsurfers in the beginning to intermediate range. Experienced surfer

programs.name: San Pablo Bay National Wildlife Refuge
programs.description: In response to rapidly disappearing wetlands and its prime location within the Pacific Flyway, the refuge was created in 1974 to protect migratory birds, wetland habitat, and endangered species. The refuge and San Pablo Bay supports the largest wintering population of canvasbacks on the west coast of the United States and protects the endangered salt marsh harvest mouse and California Ridgway's rail. The San Pablo Bay National Wildlife Refuge lies along the north shore of San Pablo Bay in Sonoma

- Camping: $25-$65 per night (varies by campsite type)

programs.fullDescription: The START (Savings for Tolling and Reduced Traffic) program provides a 50% discount on express lane tolls for income-eligible drivers on I-880 and I-80 express lanes in Alameda County.

programs.howToGetIt:

programs.name: Bay Area Casual Carpool
programs.description: Free rides for passengers; reduced tolls and HOV access for drivers
programs.fullDescription: Casual carpooling (also called "slugging") is an informal ridesharing system where drivers pick up passengers at designated locations to meet carpool requirements for bridge tolls and HOV lanes.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free rides for passengers to San Francisco
- Reduced bridge tolls for drivers (carpool rate)
- HOV lane access for drivers

programs.howToGetIt:
1. Find a casual carpool pickup location near you
2. Line up at designated spots during commute hours
3. Drivers pull up and passengers get in
4. Ride is free for passengers
5. Drivers benefit from carpool toll rates and HOV access
programs.keywords: casual carpool, slugging, free ride, HOV, bridge toll, Bay Bridge, carpool lane, commute, San Francisco, East Bay

programs.name: BikeLink Bike Lockers
programs.description: Secure 24/7 bike parking at 5/hour at BART stations
programs.fullDescription: BikeLink operates secure electronic bike lockers at BART stations and transit hubs throughout the Bay Area. These on-demand lockers are available 24/7 and rent for just 5 cents per hour.

- Available 24/7, no reservation needed

programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get a BikeLink card ($20, includes $20 of rental credit)
2. Or download the BikeLink app

5. Same to unlock when returning
programs.keywords: BikeLink, bike locker, secure bike parking, BART, transit, bicycle storage, 5 cents, e-locker, bike commute

programs.name: Bikeep Free Bike Parking at BART

programs.fullDescription: Bikeep smart bike racks at select BART stations provide free secure bike parking. The racks feature industrial-grade steel locking arms and electronic security with zero theft incidents reported across 1 million parking sessions.

- Smart locking arm secures frame and wheel
- 24-hour maximum continuous parking

- Works with registered Clipper card

1. Register online at bikehub.com (takes 30 seconds)
2. Link your physical Clipper card to your account
3. Find an available Bikeep rack at the station

programs.keywords: Bikeep, free bike parking, BART, secure, Clipper, smart rack, bicycle, bike commute, BikeHub

programs.name: Caltrain
programs.description: Peninsula commuter rail with bike parking and station amenities
programs.fullDescription: Caltrain is a commuter rail line serving the San Francisco Peninsula and Santa Clara Valley, running from San Francisco to Gilroy. Stations offer bike parking, car parking, and transit connections.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Commuter rail service from SF to Gilroy
- BikeLink e-lockers at most stations (5/hour)
- Parking at most stations ($5.50/day or $82.50/month)
- Free parking at stations south of San Jose Diridon
- Accessible stations with elevators at select locations
- Restrooms at SF, San Jose Diridon, and pilot stations
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Plan your trip at caltrain.com
2. Buy tickets at station vending machines or use Clipper card

programs.name: Bay Area ADA Paratransit
programs.description: Door-to-door transit for people with disabilities who cannot use regular buses/trains
programs.fullDescription: ADA Paratransit is a shared-ride, door-to-door transportation service for people who cannot use regular public transit due to a disability. Bay Area transit agencies provide coordinated paratransit service with regional certificationeligibility with one operator grants access to all Bay Area paratransit programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Door-to-door pickup and drop-off service
- Shared rides via small buses, vans, taxis, or sedans
- Service available during same hours as regular fixed-route transit
- Regional certification accepted by all Bay Area operators
- Personal care attendants ride free
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact your local transit agency to request an application
2. Complete the ADA paratransit eligibility application
3. You may need to complete an in-person assessment
4. Once certified, you can use paratransit across the Bay Area
5. Call 511 and say "paratransit" then your city name for local info
programs.keywords: paratransit, ADA, accessible transit, disability transportation, door to door, wheelchair accessible, 511

4. Once certified, call to schedule rides
